instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message:
Got a strange <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in today - clean board no spillage - was quite a thick layer of dust on the top of it which i've cleaned off but have been unable to find any signs of corrosion anywhere.
Board powers up but gives no display at all - caps lock doesn't react, usb mouse doesn't light up, pram reset does nothing. CPU is getting warm however. Any suggestions on where to start checking this one as i'm at a loss i've not seen this kind of problem before which was not caused by a spill!

Update - Considered this one has a dead CPU thread is now referring to the board with problems described in post #6

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message:
You can try known good working BIOS.
Do you get VCORE?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message:
Sounds like it is brain dead.  Lots of things can cause this.  2informatics is right about the bios.  There could be corrosion under the CPU or there could be a memory failure.  If it does not properly load bios and move on it will do this.

check your 3V3 SUS, make sure your bios chip is getting power.  If you have thermal look at out booting.   When the CPU loads bios and starts it's cycle you can see the RAM chips flash with activity.  Make sure your 25Mhz clock is alive.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message:
Thanks for you replies:
Yes VCORE is present 1.05V, checked 3V3 SUS which is also present - have checked and have 3.3v at BIOS chip. 

Does anyone have a known good bios for this board? I've never had to flash this one before!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message:
VCORE is aprox 1.8V on this board, at L7310/20.
Lot of links for BIOS already posted, just use search function.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message:
i usually check cpu power at the caps above the cpu but can confirm at L7310 the voltage is 1.8v. I've tried a clean bios posted on the forum for this board but still nothing no display. Are we looking at a dead CPU?
I should add I checked for voltage on the 25mhz and 32khz pins out of <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and they appear to be there (I don't have a scope but voltage there)

Assuming that this board has a dead CPU we can consider it scrap.

I have another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which again appears clean but is stuck in S5 power state - orange light on charger. <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> missing reads 0v - I was toying with the idea of swapping <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> on this one although it does seem to be producing an output on pin 12 but nothing on pins 4 and 3. All other prerequisites for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> appear to be present (<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>)
Any thoughts on this one?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>?
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message:
Yes <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> is 3.3v and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> is 1.08V. When triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> I get slightly strange behaviour on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> - <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> starts at a low voltagev 1v or so when I first apply power once I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> the voltage drops to 0v and then back up to 3.43v afterwards - it drops normally when triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>. 

Should probably add that i'm testing this board with just the 6 pin power connection connected from the I/O board to force it to turn on when connecting power.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> is 1.08V"
That's no good; should be 3V
Check again, as board should not even try to turn on.
Unless you mean just catched a pulse of about 1V; repeat and you should get higher values.
O-scope can show 3.3V peak pulse...

"All other prerequisites for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> appear to be present (<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>)"
Post exact voltages.
In case you made a wrong assumption like for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> value...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message:
Thanks yeah I must've caught the pulse at 1.08v when I measured it earlier it's a steady 3.2v
Other voltages:
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_BAT_LOW_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals should pulse at same time.
If note, PCH is suspect now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message:
Checked it - couldnt see any reaction of any <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL> signal when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> was triggered. Luckily I've found another 820-000165A board in my pile of boards i've previously replaced and have got that one working with a new clock chip. Customer now happy so thats the main thing.

Is the CPU / PCH dieing on the 820-000165 a common fault? I seem to seeing far more weird faults with this board vs to the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> series that came before!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message: Sadly yes. I notice it a lot as well

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message: Check L8304 for high resistance or damage; I have had quite a few with an issue here in one wholesale batch or repairs i did.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Powers Up, No Chime no Display
threads.message: L8304 has nothing to do with no POST.
